Award.AwardTitle: Electron Correlation Beyond the Random Phase Approximation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Filipp Furche of the University of California, Irvine is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to carry out research on electron correlation beyond the random phase approximation (RPA). The central hypothesis of this project is that RPA offers a better starting point for accurate and efficient electron correlation treatments than existing methods based on semi-local density functional or Hartree-Fock theory. The newly developed methods will be applied to problems that are difficult or impossible to treat with currently available electronic structure methods, including bond activation by transition-metal clusters, lanthanide and actinide complexes with small gaps, and multipole-bound anions.

Electronic structure calculations are indispensable tools for research and development in chemistry, materials and energy science, engineering, and biology. The methods developed in this project will be made available in a timely fashion through the Turbomole quantum chemistry software, which has a growing and diverse user community in both academia and industry. The PI is also involved in educational and outreach activities to bring computational chemistry to a broader group of scientists, including students at undergraduate institutions with large minority populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has led to the development of new first-principles methods for electronic structure calculations. These methods enable the prediction of molecular properties for a vast amount of compounds without empirical knowledge and may be used, e.g., for research and development in fundamental science, materials and drug design, or catalyst development. The methods developed here make it possible to systematically improve and correct the results of standard semi-local density functional calculations, especially for systems where few or no alternatives to validate such calculations exist.

 

A particularly important achievement was the development of random-phase approximation (RPA) renormalized many-body perturbation theory (MBPT). This method uses the RPA as starting point to systematically determine higher-order corrections. As opposed to perturbation theories starting from non-interacting electrons, RPA-renormalized MBPT is applicable to d- and f-element compounds with open shells, and thus overcomes a key limitation of existing perturbative schemes such as second-rder Moller-Plesset theory. Other important developments include a method to make meta-generalized gradient approximation functionals gauge invariant in time-dependent density functional theory, an efficient implementation of RPA first-order properties and other algorithmic improvements widening the scope of RPA-type methods. 

 

Application of these methods in collaboration with the group of Professor William J. Evans has led to the discovery of 8 new lanthanide and actinide ions so far. The properties of these new species represent a radical departure from traditional f-element chemistry and may lead to new small-molecule activation methods, analytical techniques, and synthetic applications in organometallic chemistry.

The materials developed in this project are being used for teaching and education of undergraduate students at UCI with no or little exposure to electronic structure methods and computational chemistry. Outreach activities included a dedicated year-long high-school outreach program in collaboration with local high schools, recruitment talks at schools with large minority populations, the AirUCI summer teacher workshop for high school teachers, tutoring at a middle school in Santa Ana, CA, and the development of a publicly available introduction to electronic structure calculations.
